title: 112_s1312
content:
The "Asset Forfeiture Responsibility Act of 2011" aims to strengthen monitoring in fisheries across the United States through the establishment of a Fisheries Investment Fund. The "Fisheries Investment Fund" is established in the Treasury's general fund to receive fines, penalties, and forfeitures for violations of marine resource laws. Funds deposited in the account are available until expended and can be used for reimbursing attorneys' fees and conducting related activities. During fiscal years 2012 and 2013, the Secretary of Commerce may reimburse the reasonable attorneys' fees of a covered person for conducting audits, enforcement, and monitoring activities related to marine resource laws. A covered person must apply for reimbursement within 60 days of the Secretary directing a fisheries enforcement penalty to be remitted. The term "covered person" includes those directed by the Secretary of Commerce or those who submitted a complaint to the Special Master before May 7, 2011. The term "reasonable attorneys' fees" refers to legal fees incurred by a covered person seeking remittance of a fisheries enforcement penalty directed by the Secretary of Commerce. The Secretary of Commerce or the Secretary of the Treasury shall prepare an annual audit plan for the Fisheries Investment Fund for fiscal years 2012, 2013, and 2014, submit it to the appropriate Inspector General, conduct the audit, and submit the final results to the Inspector General. Authorization of Appropriations for the Fisheries Investment Fund includes reimbursement of attorneys' fees, audit expenses, and enforcement activities under the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act. The Fisheries Investment Fund authorizes appropriations for monitoring activities under the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act, with a limit of 33% of the total remaining amount in the Fund. The total remaining amount in the Fund is defined as fines, penalties, and forfeitures received by the United States in the previous fiscal year. The Fisheries Investment Fund authorizes appropriations for monitoring activities under marine resource laws enforced by the Secretary of Commerce. The amount deposited in the Fund for each fiscal year is adjusted to account for reimbursements and audits. The Fisheries Investment Fund authorizes appropriations for monitoring activities under marine resource laws enforced by the Secretary of Commerce, including the amount necessary for conducting audits for the current fiscal year. The Fisheries Investment Fund authorizes appropriations for monitoring activities under marine resource laws enforced by the Secretary of Commerce, including conducting audits for the current fiscal year. Additionally, Section 4 specifies the use of funds for monitoring. The Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act is amended to allow the Secretary to pay for monitoring activities from the Fisheries Investment Fund, prioritizing at-sea observers, shoreside monitoring, fishery impact statements, and other priorities set by Councils to maintain sustainable fisheries and ecosystems. The Magnuson-Stevens Act is amended to allocate funds from the Fisheries Investment Fund for monitoring activities among Councils based on the proportion of violations in their jurisdiction. SEC. 5. USE OF FUNDS FOR ENFORCEMENT.

Amends the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act to allow the Secretary to use funds from the Fisheries Investment Fund for enforcement activities. Removes a subparagraph and adjusts the positioning of another paragraph.

SEC. 6. EFFECTIVE DATE. The Act and its amendments will apply to sums received after the enactment date.
